thread.title: Christmas markets: river cruises to Europe's best
thread.title_full: Christmas markets: river cruises to Europe's best - Telegraph

author: Pat Richardson
title: Christmas markets: river cruises to Europe's best
text: Whether you go to buy gifts, replenish your Yuletide larder or simply to soak up the atmosphere, Europe’s Christmas markets weave a captivating spell. While snowfall cannot be guaranteed, it is more likely. At the very least you can expect a Christmas-card setting with traditional handmade decorations, along with daytime and evening markets packed with festive flavours and, if you’re lucky, local choirs providing the requisite soundtrack. • Why I hate Christmas markets It is possible to cruise by river or sea to enjoy Europe’s markets. The advantage with river cruising is the opportunity to visit not just one but several Christmas markets and, as you sail, to see towns and villages decorated for the festive season. The biggest concentration of Christmas markets lies along the banks of the Rhine and the Danube ; there are also some on the Main and the Seine – many in Paris itself. There are still plenty of end-of-year cruises to choose from, but you’ll have to be quick. All the cruises listed here are full board and include return flight unless stated. The Rhine The highlights: the Rhine Gorge, lined with castles and charming toes-in-the-water towns and villages; imposing Cologne Cathedral; picturesque Strasbourg. Cruise this river, which weaves through the heart of Germany, and you’ll be able to enjoy German Christmas markets in Rudesheim, Koblenz and Cologne on a four-day trip with The River Cruise Line (0844 544 6437; rivercruiseline.co.uk ). Its cruises are on board the Lady Anne with departures on December 1, 4, 7, 10 and 13 2015. From £269 per person including coach travel. Or, on board Serenity, take a four-day trip from Mainz, which includes Christmas markets in Mannheim, Heidelberg and Strasbourg – thought to be Europe’s oldest, dating from 1570. Departs on December 8 and 11 2015. From £399 per person (no single supplement) including coach or Eurostar travel. Cologne Cathedral Photo: GETTY Choose from seven themed Christmas markets in Cologne, and seven in Düsseldorf, or visit markets in Cologne, Bonn and Koblenz with Saga (0800 096 0079; travel.saga.co.uk ), which offers these three and four-night cruises on Regina Rheni II, departing on December 13 and 16 2015. The cruises cost from £269 or £499 per person including coach or Eurostar travel and breakfast (pay separately for dinners). Single cabins at no extra cost. • How to visit Father Christmas in Lapland Christmas markets in Strasbourg and Heidelberg also feature on a round-trip cruise from Cologne with Archers Holidays (0800 997 8719; archersdirect.co.uk ), which sells this four-night cruise on A-Rosa Viva, departing on December 3 2015. From £799 per person. Markets in Aachen, Rüdesheim, Heidelberg, Baden-Baden, Strasbourg, Colmar and Riquewihr feature on an eight-day Basel-to-Cologne cruise offered by luxury US operator Tauck (0800 810 8020; tauck.co.uk ), departing on December 13 2015. From £1,595 per person, excluding flights. The Rhine and Main The highlights: on the Main, some of Germany’s oldest cities, including Bamberg and Wurzburg. One river not enough? Cruise the Rhine and Main to see markets in Amsterdam, Cologne, Rudesheim and Bamberg, and Wurzburg’s Bishops’ Residenz on an eight-day cruise with Emerald Waterways (0808 271 9294; emeraldwaterways.co.uk ) departing on November 28 2015. From £2,195 per person. Picturesque Amsterdam Photo: GETTY The Danube The highlights: a wealth of imperial palaces, Melk’s magnificent 11th-century Benedictine Abbey, capital cities Vienna and Budapest and the scenic Wachau Valley. With hot punch and chestnut stands, markets and classical concerts, Vienna comes into its own in December. The biggest market is held in front of the imposing City Hall, while the baroque Belvedere Palace makes an equally impressive backdrop for the 40-plus stalls called Christmas Village. It’s a little farther from the centre, but don’t miss the atmospheric, year-round Nachtmarkt for its amazing foodstuffs. A classical music concert is included on Uniworld’s River Princess (0800 988 5873; titantravel.co.uk ), which sails from Nuremberg to Vienna on December 15 2015 costing from £1,779 per person. If you’d like an exclusive tour of Frankfurt’s Thurn und Taxis Palace, with a visit to its private Bavarian Christmas Market, Tauck includes both on its eight-day cruise from Nuremberg to Vienna on its ship Savor, departing on December 12 2015 (from £1,620 per person, excluding flights). Or, from Nuremberg, sail on to Bratislava and Budapest to experience a traditional Hungarian farewell dinner with folk-dancing. Emerald Waterways offers this eight-day cruise, departing on December 5 2015 from £2,795 per person. Grand Vienna Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Another Nuremberg to Budapest cruise begins with a visit to the world’s largest Christmas market and includes another in medieval Regensburg, and visits the Imperial Schönbrunn Palace with its 60 traditional stalls. There’s an optional excursion to Salzburg. Sail on AmaSonata, on November 25 2015. From £1,699 per person (0808 256 8422; amawaterways.co.uk ). The Seine The highlights: the river snakes through Normandy’s rural landscape; cruises start and end in Paris, and also call at Rouen. Lighting up Notre Dame Photo: GETTY The City of Light puts on a spectacular display for the festive season, including the Champs-Élysées illuminations (6pm until 2am) and Christmas Market, stretching from Rond-point to Place de la Concorde’s Ferris wheel. Among the markets is the Branly Promenade near the Eiffel Tower (December 17 to January 3). See Paris dressed for Christmas and enjoy a private tour of Versailles on an eight-day Paris to Normandy cruise with Titan on the River Baroness, departing on December 6, 13 and 20 2015. The Christmas day sailing includes dinner. From £2,099 per person. Christmas day cruises Most markets will have closed by December 23, but on board you can expect seasonal menus and a convivial atmosphere. Enjoy private musical performances in Budapest and Vienna, a journey on an imperial train and a banquet at Namedy Castle on a 15-day cruise with APT (0800 046 3002; aptouring.co.uk ). It is on AmaVenita and costs from £4,295 per person. Avalon Waterways (0800 668 1801; avaloncruises.co.uk ) sails the other way, from Amsterdam to Budapest, with visits to Melk Abbey and the magnificent Bishop’s Residenz. The 14-night cruise is on Avalon Vista departing on December 21. From £4,927 per person. The River Cruise Line offers a 10-day Christmas and a nine-day New Year cruise on the Danube on board Serenity, departing on December 20 and 27. From £1,099 and £999 per person including coach travel. Voyages Jules Verne (0845 166 7378; vjv.com ) has a four or five-night Danube cruise round-trip from Vienna, on board Vivaldi. Midnight Mass and a Christmas Day performance of The Nutcracker in Budapest are included. From £1,445 per person (no single supplement), departing on December 22. This article was first published on May 8, 2014, and updated in full on October 23, 2015 Telegraphtravel
